comments.commentBody:
Okay, now you can see the thought process (such as it is) while the coffee's still brewing...

a) I clear my circuits
b) I sense the hidden message
c) I find it...maybe
d) I find it...for sure

The answer is d: March fourth

Pretty noir, by dawn's early light...and to think, if I weren't such a leapfinger, all this could have been one compressed into a single (shorter) reply ...(sigh)
This puzzle brings back memories, doesn't it, John.  Or haven't you had time to do it yet?

Hi John - where are you in Maine? My son lives in Belfast, after three years in Presque Isle.
When I was a kid, my family had a summer home in Kennebunk Beach.
I love Maine - so many beautiful places, and clean fresh air.
Leapy, we are still in Maine watching basketball games our grandsons play in.  Thanks for the safe passage.  Now if you would learn the difference between Bataan and baton....

It was indeed a pleasure to read about the lives of Fred and Wendy.  I have been the beneficiary of attending FotoFest in 2008 and 2010 and will be there again in a few weeks.  I am very surprised at the openness of Wendy.  She reviewed my portfolio at Photolucida and was very open to my style of interpretive, composite photography.  Thank you Wendy.
lovely!
cry a life-time dear son. poet's peace. thank you Rodrigo Abd & Lens & NYT.

Excellent reportage with a crystalline message, made under dangerous and difficult circumstances. My congratulations to Mr. Abd. As I look in LENS at the works of such supremely talented individuals--Mr. Aranda and Mr. Hicks come to mind, among many others-- the common thread that comes to mind more and more is not so much the technique, the skill, the artistrty, or even the courage to do this dangerous work; but the intense engagement in our shared humanity. Mr. Abd, be careful. Syria's people would be more silenced without you.
this is my first visit to your site. wonderful,  enjoyed it very much.

Yes, it is invasive, but it is also a way of making us aware what goes on in other parts of the world.

It is truly heart wrenching to see the inequalities and sufferings many people, especially children in some parts of the world has to endure.

Is there anything we can do to help the Syrians in particular?

Does this sort of photograph require a model release form?  I mean that in all sincerity.  It seems terribly invasive, at a most inopportune moment and to think of the photographer reaping praise and money at the boy's expense is unsettling to me.  I know it's a difficult topic but what are the proper boundaries here?

Great! Men who love women are sorely needed to step up and Man Up! Beating and raping women is not manly behavior.

Thank you.

Blessed Be.

FRED AND WENDY´S TORRID AFFAIR KEEPS WORKING !...AND SEEMS THEY INSPIRE MORE AND MORE PEOPLE INTO THE LOVE FOR PHOTOGRAPHY. FOR ME, TO KNOW  THEM WAS A TURNING POINT IN MY LIFE .... I´VE LEARNED SOOO MANY GOOD THINGS FROM THEM....I´M EAGER TO SEE THEIR BOOK !

The anguish, pain, agony and feeling of loss on this boy's face is just too much to bear .... Is there any thing we can do to help him believe that there is good in this world?? He has just lost his father, his only pillar of strength in this life, and possibly the only source of income for this family. Can we have more information about his circumstances, please????

As a father, this tears my soul apart. War photographers have a dirty job but unless they do it, the world can conveniently ignore the suffering of fellow humans that are out of sight. This forces us to  contemplate, grieve and love, all at the same time. A timely image as the  war drums for attacking Iran grow louder.

This picture breaks my heart. I was sitting in a crowded cafe at lunch yesterday with my paper, and I was trying not to look at the picture and  trying not to cry. But, I couldn't help it. For a few moments  that boy and I were the same.  My own father died of a gunshot when I was a boy.

Happy Trails, Bill and Gail...
Oh, btw, that was a most impressive time!
Cherrio 2U2

WHH

John, I'm aghast! How extremely Rouge of you, and with my LeapyL, no less! Name your weapon, sir!

WHH

As a long-time Audubon member, it is snowy owl. But I got it, so call it poetic license?

http://www.pbase.com/macknight/image/55509253

Mac

Please read the history of India.What happened in Muslim era and British rule we Indians surrendered before them just like sheep.Our psyche is responsible for that.Teaching of Hindu religion was responsible for our meekness..Hindu philosophy given importance to [ MOKSHA ] liberation of bondage of life and death. Our philosophy given mundane life negligible value That is why we remain poor for centuries.After all eccentric monsoon is also responsible for this pessimistic philosophy.
Only solution to our this horrible plight is to bring new technologies, it has power to changes the society.From 1991 as we accepted liberation of economy and we Indians are very delightedly adopting new technologies just like Internet mobile we are now tremendously progressing all field.

As an Indian who grew up in England but returned to embrace my homeland, I am immeasurably saddened by what has happened to my beloved country. With its baggage of colonialism, rampant corruption since independence and above all, a karmic tendency to submit meekly to what seems inevitable, India is a nation raped by the past, present and now the future. We just don't know who we are and what we want. We're so used to short cuts now, that any formula for success will do. I can rationalize everything, but it doesn't make the pain go away.

Rush Limpbug is the guiding light of the far right wing of the Repgnican party.

Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative. John Stuart Mill

Well Bill from NC, you ae good at misstating the issue.

It is not forcing employers to provide this medication free, it is that their medical insurance must provide it, and most employees pay for some part of their medical insurance. But some employers want to be able to tell the insurance plan to not provide certain medications. They are not demanding anything free of charge, they just want it included in their health plans. And, yes health plans do pay pay for vasectomies.

Where do you get off saying women want their health care free? Where did anyone other than you conservatives make this statement?

To me, it's not as important that he understand how and when to use "y'all" or enjoy grits as it is, for me, to have him explain why he keeps his money offshore rather than in American banks (an issue upon which he has NEVER commented, that I can find).
It seems to me that decision demonstrates a real lack of faith in our nation -- a poor quality in one who claims aspirations toward the presidency.
The other day, I heard a reporter say that Mr. Romney was "running out of money" and needed to fundraise more because he was burning through millions as the primaries marched by.
Interesting it was apparently not HIS money he was running out of -- because his money is safely secreted away from trouble and the tax man.
Makes me wonder what attitude he would take toward OUR tax dollars.
When he was governor, it was a different time and the economy had not been through such drastic strain.
Now that it's getting better slowly, however, Mr. Romney doesn't seem to want to acknowledge the progress it is attaining so far.
He doesn't seem to understand the value of slow and steady improvement.
All he seems to advocate is to return to the same policies that dragged us into the pit in the first place.

Cash vouchers for food have been shown to increase consumption and health but only in areas where there is actually food in markets to purchase. I'm not sure this is the case this winter in N Korea. Also given the type of closed economy that N Korea has monetary assistance wouldn't be the best option.
Truth be known, current and past US governments are full of war criminals, starting with Kissinger and continuing to Bush/Cheney/Obama.  Only America's muscle protects them.

Easy, easy answer: What does a take over specialist, one who does what he "has always done," want? The Presidency? No! His eyes are on a bigger prize--the treasury--the largest pot of wealth and the executive authority of the largest economy--in the history of the world! The only way to get there is to be President. So we have a massive "take over" attack, a raid by Super-PACs, a candidacy short on policy and long on boilerplate (which proposes increases in the defense!), which is undertaking a hostile take over, in order to gain an incredible prize: the keys to the Treasury. Imagine what he could do.

That's his Everest. [Here's what the WSJ says about his chances Tuesday: http://wp.me/p1mBVu-H5]
Thanks for the movie reference, Judge. I just watched it on Amazon Prime on my Kindle Fire. Very inspiring to a long-term NYT XWD puzzle addict.

Yeah. In my current re-start of my fairly successful demand forecasting management software company, I am contemplating exactly that strategy. First time around, 20 years ago, demand was so strong and competition so limited that pricing was not an issue.

It works for online dating services and for Microsoft itself - they give away starter compilers and charge for upgrades. Maybe it will work for me, and I certainly do not think that profit from software is immoral.

I do think that it is immoral to make millions from fraudulent financial schemes which skirt and mock the regulations intended to keep them fair. I gave both food and money contributions to the Occupy San Francisco people (both of them) on Market St outside the Federal Reserve building this morning. The fifty-plus police were there, it turned out, because of the nude bicycle ride which swept through, not because of the Occupiers.

Profit yes, fraud no.

Bill at realamerica.webs.com

I've noticed a disgusting trend around the facility. Many long years ago, nobody missed the ceramics. Now, would it were so. Hygiene has been displaced by indifference and/or downright contempt. Sometimes I think this has become a theater for self-expression against social mores, a kind of protest and assertion of masculine dominance. Even so, there are worse things. Around truck stops bottles of body fluids accumulate, indiscriminately scattered on the ground as if cholera were not a consequence. Increased demands and pressures on drivers who are only paid by the mile have compelled ad hoc solutions. The capitalist theme of self-interest has put us all against each other, against common interest along with public health.
